item.title: Theme Documentation - Basics
item.author: Author
item.description: Discover what the Hugo - LoveIt theme is all about and the core-concepts behind it.

item.title: Theme Documentation - Content
item.author: Author
item.description: Find out how to create and organize your content quickly and intuitively in LoveIt theme.

item.title: Emscripten
item.author: Author
item.description: Emscripten As it happens, we can’t actually build native plugins since VSCode is built off Javascript/Typescript. I have a vague memory of setting up Emscripten in the past and it not being that painful to setup, but this experience was less than pleasant. The major issue I ran into was that ‘emcc.bat’ calls ‘Python’ but the default version of Python that I use is 32-bit while the binaries included in most standard versions of Emscript are 64-bit.

item.title: Theme Documentation - Built-in Shortcodes
item.author: Author
item.description: Hugo provides multiple built-in shortcodes for author convenience and to keep your markdown content clean.

item.title: Theme Documentation - Extended Shortcodes
item.author: Author
item.description: LoveIt theme provides multiple shortcodes on top of built-in ones in Hugo.

item.title: Basic Markdown Syntax
item.author: Author
item.description: This article offers a sample of basic Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files.

item.title: Emoji Support
item.author: Author
item.description: Emoji can be enabled in a Hugo project in a number of ways.

item.author: Author
item.description: AppVeyor Explorations After my very positive experience with Travis CI (see Homepage Build), I decided it was time to take a look at some Windows options for builds. This led me very quickly to AppVeyor. But unfortunately, I don’t have a Windows project to test this on, so I made one up. I’ve long been a fan of DosBox and since I follow DosNostalgic I can’t help but be reminded daily of how much I love past games.

item.author: Author
item.description: Introduction Turns out deep learning is kind of a big deal right now and for good reason. It’s cool, powerful, GPU-friendly, and just pretty great. I wanted to be a part of the fun and realized it wasn’t as easy to do for Windows developers. But the good news is that it is actually supported. Found this useful: https://www.quora.com/How-does-Enthought-Canopy-compare-to-Anaconda The stack: Anaconda x64 (https://www.continuum.io/downloads) Make sure to select the 64-bit version!

item.author: Author
item.description: Dev Notes (Oct 22, 2017) Traveling is always my most productive time for random thoughts and coding exercises. Doesn’t always mean clean code in fact it basically never does, but I always have a list of topics I’d like to explore and then when on a plane I finally have time to do that. This time I tackled a few topics: SQLite-net Reveal.js Browser extensions (webpack, TypeScript) Reveal.js For work, I create presentations using PowerPoint quite a bit.
